tips: Keep this plan updated, and remember you can always reach out if things escalate.
Start packing small items now so you’re ready when you decide to leave.
It’s normal to feel unsettled, refer back to this plan whenever you need a safety reminder.

warmUp.text: What city do you live in?
warmUp.tips: Save the local support numbers for {city} in your phone’s speed-dial so you can call immediately if you need help.

warmUp.text: Which room in your home feels the safest if you need to get away quickly?
warmUp.tips: Keep your essentials (phone, keys, and a small flashlight) in {safe_room} so you can grab them instantly when you need to leave.

tips: Let those you live with: {family/roommates} know your safe room and cue‐word so they can support you in an emergency.
Since you live alone, identify a trusted neighbor or friend and share your safe room location with them.
Because you live with your partner, keep your safety plan hidden (in {safe_room}), and consider storing a digital copy in a password-protected note they won’t see.

warmUp.followupTextPrompt: Enter a code word for your children
tips: Practice your safety plan with your children so that when they hear {code_word},they know exactly what to do.
Even without children, it helps to identify a second safe space in your home.

Still in a relationship.text: Which form(s) of abuse are you experiencing?
Still in a relationship.tips: If you face {abuse_type} abuse, remember you don’t have to face it alone. Reach out to your emergency contact right away.

tips: Log each incident (date, time, and a brief note) so you have clear records if needed later.
Even brief notes on your phone can be helpful. Start logging today.

Still in a relationship.text: Name one person you can call immediately in an emergency.
Still in a relationship.tips: Save {contact_name} in your phone under a code-word so you can quietly call them when you need help.

Planning to leave.text: When do you plan to leave?
Planning to leave.tips: Set a real target {leave_timing} and pack one essential item each day until you’re ready.

Planning to leave.text: Do you have a go-bag packed?
tips: Great! Keep your go-bag in a hidden spot so you can grab it quickly.
Pack a simple go-bag today with essentials like your ID, some cash, and a charger.

Planning to leave.text: Where do you keep emergency cash or cards?
Planning to leave.tips: Stash some cash and a spare card in {money_location}, a spot your partner won’t suspect.

Planning to leave.text: Have you identified a safe place to stay?
tips: Make sure {temp_shelter} knows you may arrive unexpectedly and how to contact you.
Reach out to Victim Services Toronto or a trusted friend now to secure a shelter option before you leave.

Post-separation.text: Has the abuser continued any contact?
tips: Since you’ve heard from them, stay vigilant and keep your protection order handy if you have one.
Even without contact, keep your doors locked and your phone on in case you need to call 911.

Post-separation.text: Do you have a protection order?
tips: Carry your {legal_order} at all times and share copies with anyone who needs to know.
Consider applying for a protection order; it can help deter unwanted contact.

Post-separation.text: Are you using any safety tools?
tips: Make sure your {equipment} is in working order and placed where you’ll notice it.
Consider installing a simple door alarm or camera to alert you to unexpected entry.

followUp.text: Which type of support would help most right now?
followUp.tips: Reach out to {support_choice} - they can offer the specialized help you need right now.
